meaning: You have a right to perform your prescribed duty, but you are not entitled to the fruits of action.

sanskrit: योगस्थः कुरु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा धनञ्जय ।
meaning: Perform your duty with steadiness of mind, abandoning attachment to success and failure.
Therefore, always perform your duty without attachment, for by doing so one attains the Supreme.

sanskrit: न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते ।
meaning: In this world, there is nothing as purifying as true knowledge.
One must elevate oneself by one’s own mind, and not degrade oneself.
One who is not disturbed by others and who does not disturb others is dear to the Lord.
All this—whatever exists in this universe—is pervaded by the Supreme.
One should desire to live a hundred years by performing actions in a spirit of renunciation.
He who sees all beings in his own Self and his own Self in all beings feels no hatred.
When a person realizes that all beings are one with the Self, what delusion or sorrow can exist?
The face of Truth is hidden by a golden disc; remove it so that I may see the truth.

sanskrit: असुर्या नाम ते लोका अन्धेन तमसाऽऽवृताः ।
meaning: Those worlds are enveloped in darkness, where people live without understanding the Self.

sanskrit: अनेजदेकं मनसो जवीयो नैनद्देवा आप्नुवन् पूर्वमर्षत् ।
meaning: The Self is unmoving, yet faster than the mind. The senses cannot reach it, for it is ever ahead.
It moves and it moves not; it is far and it is near; it is within all and outside all.
The Self is all-pervading, pure, bodiless, untouched by sin, and self-existent.
Those who follow ignorance enter darkness; those who worship knowledge alone enter even greater darkness.
He who knows both knowledge and action together crosses death through action and attains immortality through knowledge.
Rama, the son of Dasharatha, was virtuous, truthful, courageous, and firmly established in Dharma.
Upholding the word of one’s father is considered the highest Dharma.

sanskrit: सत्यं धर्मः परो लोके सत्ये धर्मः प्रतिष्ठितः ।
meaning: Truth is the supreme Dharma in this world; Dharma itself is established upon truth.
One should renounce desire and material gain and always remember Dharma.

sanskrit: अनृतं न वदेत् किञ्चित् धर्मे स्थित्वा नरः सदा ।
meaning: A person established in Dharma should never speak falsehood.
For the welfare of all beings, one should always act according to Dharma.
Dharma should never be abandoned, whether in happiness or sorrow.

sanskrit: धर्मेण राज्यं कुरुते स राजा सुखमेधते ।
meaning: A king who rules according to Dharma ensures happiness and prosperity.
Rama was well-versed in Dharma, educated, and compassionate towards all beings.
One should protect one’s life, but never abandon Dharma for the sake of life.

sanskrit: धर्म एव हतो हन्ति धर्मो रक्षति रक्षितः ।
meaning: Dharma destroys those who violate it and protects those who uphold it.
Rama never abandoned Dharma even when overcome by anger.
Non-violence is the highest Dharma and is beneficial for all beings.
Contentment is the greatest happiness, rooted in Dharma.

sanskrit: धैर्यं धर्मस्य मूलं स्यात् सर्वकार्येषु शोभनम् ।
meaning: Patience is the foundation of Dharma and brings excellence in all actions.

sanskrit: क्षमा धर्मस्य भूषणं वीराणां च विशेषतः ।
meaning: Forgiveness is the ornament of Dharma, especially for the strong.

sanskrit: धर्मात् न विचलत्येव यः स पन्थाः सनातनः ।
meaning: The eternal path is the one that never deviates from Dharma.
A ruler must protect his people by governing strictly according to Dharma.
